Further Variants of Coverage Criteria 14 Coverage Criteria â€¢ Loop boundary adequacy criterion: For every loop, one test case exercises the loop zero times, one test case exercises the loop once, one test case exercises the loop multiple times. â€¢ MC/DC (Modified Condition/Decision Coverage): Exercise each condition in a way that it can, independently of the other conditions, affect the outcome of the entire decision. In short, this means that every possible condition of each parameter must have influenced the outcome at least once Black-box Testing Black-Box Testing 16 Black-Box Testing (Funktionstest) â€¢ test-case design based on specification â€¢ source code and its inner structure is ignored (assumed as a black-box) Equivalence Class Testing â€¢ idea: classify inputs and outputs into equivalence classes â€¢ assumption: equivalent test cases detect the same faults, one test case is sufficient Boundary Testing â€¢ extension of equivalence class testing â€¢ goal: use experience (e.g., off-by-one errors) â€¢ for every equivalence class: consider smallest, typical, and largest value Motivation â€¢ source code not always available (e.g., outsourced components, obfuscated code) â€¢ specific test cases derived from logical ones using arbitrary values â€¢ specification not incorporated so far (only for expected results) â€¢ invalid inputs not tested â€¢ errors are not equally distributed In Practice â€¢ Often combinations of white-box and black- box testing Equivalence Class Testing 17 /** * Computes the remainder of the * Euclidean division of a by b. Unit vs. Integration Test In unit tests â€œexternal componentsâ€œ are replaced by â€œmocksâ€œ Unit vs. Integration Test â–ª Mocks are replaced in integration tests by actual implementations. â–ª Focus on inter-component functionality â–ª Database â€“ Controller â€“ UI Summary 28 White-box and Black-box testing â€¢ In white box testing, the structure of a program is used to derive good test cases â€¢ In black-box testing, the specification is leveraged to derive good test cases â€¢ In practice, you usually start with black-box testing (based on the requirements) and then you augment your test suite with test cases that increase code coverage (white- box testing) â€¢ JUnit is a great framework to integrate testing practices directly in Java programs
